anchor.surface_text: The remuneration provided for the appellants brother was out of the profits and there was payable if there was a loss and the High Court was wrong in thinking that the appellants brother was entitled to his remuneration whether there was profit or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of deed: remuneration out of profits only

anchor.surface_text: In re Ambalal Sarabhai the High Court of Bombay has held that the fact that the companytrol of the business is kept with one partner and that he has certain extra rights as a major partner does number in any sense negative the partnership according to law.

precedents.cited_proposition: the fact that the control of the business is kept with one partner and that he has certain extra rights as a major partner does not in any sense negative the partnership according to law; it is open to two partners to allow the business of partnership to be conducted by one of the partners
precedents.cited_holding: upheld the assessee's plea of partnership between husband and wife on construction of the document despite it being unusual

precedents.citation: Raghunandan Nanu Kothare v. Hormasji Bezonjee Bamjee

anchor.surface_text: Raghunandan Nanu Kothare v. Hormasji Bezonjee Bamjee, after companystruing an agreement of partnership between two solicitors the High Court reversed the trial companyrts finding that the defendant was number a partner but was an agent of the plaintiff, and came to the companyclusion that the agreement made the defendant a partner of the plaintiff.

precedents.case_name: Raghunandan Nanu Kothare v. Hormasji Bezonjee Bamjee
precedents.cited_proposition: an agreement can create partnership even if the junior partner has fixed remuneration in lieu of profit share and no responsibility for losses or liabilities
precedents.cited_holding: defendant was a partner despite no loss liability and fixed monthly payment, given parties' conduct as experienced solicitors acting as partners for years

anchor.surface_text: Robinson v. Ashton where it has been held that in the absence of any special agreement the mill which belonged to R, one of the partners, and the value of which was credited in the books of the partnership as capital of the firm was an asset of the partnership.

precedents.cited_proposition: in the absence of any special agreement, property belonging to one partner credited as capital in partnership books becomes a partnership asset against which firm liabilities can be enforced
precedents.cited_holding: the mill belonging to one partner was an asset of the partnership
